H0.text: Chemical reaction is the cause of rust formation when iron combines with oxygen in a moist environment.

H1.text: Physical reaction is why rust forms when iron combines with oxygen in a moist environment.

H2.text: Change in density causes rust to form when iron combines with oxygen in a moist environment.

H3.text: Change in temperature is the reason rust forms when iron combines with oxygen in a moist environment.

A4.text: The rusting of iron is an electrochemical process that begins with the transfer of electrons from iron to oxygen.

A5.text: When iron rusts, the oxides take up more volume than the original metal; this expansion can generate enormous forces, damaging structures made with iron.

A6.text: The formation of iron(III) oxide (Fe₂O₃) occurs through the chemical reaction 4 Fe + 3 O₂ → 2 Fe₂O₃, which is a direct cause of rust when iron combines with oxygen.

A7.text: The rusting of iron is an electrochemical process involving the transfer of electrons from iron to oxygen, as described in the text.
